title: Casualty airs shocking child murderer storyline
text:
Desperate situation (Picture: BBC)

Casualty is never afraid to explore the more troubling aspects of the human condition, and tonight they told the story of a man with a past so dreadful that even the usually caring and professional Robyn (Amanda Henderson) refused to work with him.

Marcus Hopewood (Rupert Hill) had killed a nine year old girl in a brutal attack with a hammer – when he was only ten years old himself. It was a story which had disturbing echoes of the killing of James Bulger in 1993. Like the killers in that case, Marcus Hopewood had eventually resumed life under a new identity (now called Daryl) and in a different location. He’d been married, had a daughter and was now divorced but without his family having any knowledge of his horrific former life.

When his daughter Jessie (Adrianna Bertola) had an accident and Hopewood (who was known then as Daryl) was filmed rescuing her, the footage went online and he was recognised. We saw the shock of the hospital staff when they realised who their patient was. The script didn’t dwell on the details of the original crime but we found out that the attack had been vicious and prolonged. Robyn was particularly troubled that the victim had been a little girl. As the mother of a little girl herself, she couldn’t bring herself to go near Hopewood.

Dylan was immediately concerned that vigilantes would track the killer down to Holby (as a Holby ambulance was seen in the online footage). That turned out to be exactly what happened, but the twist was that the vigilante was Lorna (Michelle Collins), the mother of the murdered child, who’d got herself admitted to the hospital so she could get revenge.

Jessie’s world turned upside down (Picture: BBC)

One of the most troubling aspects of the story was the realisation by Hopewood’s daughter Jessie that the father she knew and loved had done this awful crime. She tried to talk to him when he refused treatment for the brain aneurysm that could kill him, and found herself in danger when Lorna held a knife to her throat. In tense scenes we learned about Hopewood’s other crimes against children, while Duffy tried to reason with Lorna and get her to put the knife down. Thanks to Duffy’s intervention Lorna realised that she couldn’t put a mother through the pain she’d been through by killing Jessie, and the girl was reunited with her mother at the end.
